fields.physical_description:
Design: 82 squared playing surface in pink, blue, yellow and green with a block of colour in each corner; crossed with single squares of the other colours, a key shape and score; edged on 2 sides by single squares of colour
No. of squares: 82
Squares illustrated: none
Square numbering: none
Squares titled: none
Subject of starting square: none
Subject of ending square: none
fields.title:
keyword
KEYWORD PATIENCE; a waddinGton crossword Game
fields.history_note:
Keyword Patience marked INVENTED BY MR NORMAN V WATSON COPYRIGHT 1953 BY JOHN WADDINGTON.
Box-compartmented card, covered with light green paper with a label on the lid.
fields.production_note: john waddington Ltd; copyright by Parker Bros. Inc. Salem, Mass USA
fields.historical_context_note:
Rewards: points to be gained
Forfeits: unable to form words
No. of Players: 2, 3 or 4
Equipment required: 4 letter racks, wood stained blue, yellow, red and green
94 black plastic squares printed with letters of the alphabet in white
2 blank squares
12 cards, dark green on reverse, printed on face with a word and score
2 sets of rules and a third showing rules for Keyword Patience


Rules:
Copyright 1953 by Parker Bros. Inc. Salem. Mass. USA Patent Application No.  6958/53
Manufactured by England by John Waddington Ltd Makers of Monopoly

Folding playing board dark green outer with label showing title and details, which are also on playing surface.  Surface shows 82 squares each of blue, pink, yellow and green, a block of colour in each square crossed with single squares of the other colours and edged on 2 sides by single squares of the other colours.  In the centre of the board are 29 beige and 4 purple squares in the shape of a + and the word Keyword horizontally and vertically in centre squares.

THE OBJECT OF THE GAME
Each player by playing his letter blocks to the cross word layout on the board tries to spell the Keyword or other words, and to play his letters on the squares that give him the largest score.  A player should try to play out all his letters before his opponents, for letters left in a player's hand at the end of play are counted against him.  The highest score wins the game.

BOARD AND KEY SQUARES
In the centre of the board there are three gray squares runningdown and three across.  These are starting squares; the first htree letters of the first word placed on the board must be placed in these squares either down or across.  The following players then build from this word in any direction they wish.
There are four colour areas on the board which correspond in colour to the players' letter block racks.  Thus if a player is using the Red rack, his colour area is all the Red squares.  He tries to place as many letters as possible in his own colour area, for letters placed by a player on any square of his own colour Count Double.  If a player places a letter on any of the Key squares he receives 20 points additional score plus 5 points for the letter played.  This score is doubled if the Key square is his own colour.

KEYWORD CARDS.
There are a number of Keyword cards.  These cards are placed at the side of the board face down.  At the start of the game the player keeping score tuns one of the Keyword cards face up.  Any player, at any time in the game, when it is his turn to play, who is able to spell this Keyword on the board receives 50 points additional score.  After a Keyword has been spelled on the board by a player, another Keyword card is turned face-up.


FURTHER FULL DETAILS OF THE RULES ARE GIVEN IN THE PHOTOCOPIES AVAILABLE 
AS ARE THE RULES FOR KEYWORD PATIENCE

Rules placement: separate sheet
